title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove

content: today we're cleaning the glass stovetop and my goal with this video is to show you the fastest and cheapest routes to do so as a business owner I avoid buying expensive products if there are effective cheaper alternatives to clean your glass stovetop all you're gonna need is a microfiber cloth some Dawn dish soap and a razor blade now I have nothing against buy an expensive appliance specific chemicals but when it comes to cleaning your glass stovetop it's completely unnecessary especially if you're someone who use your stovetop a lot you're gonna be cleaning a lot now if you're someone that never cooks and you just want your stove top shiny and pretty kind of like decoration for your kitchen then go ahead and buy the product specific cleaner shine it up set it forget it but I promise you the simple two-step process I'm going to show you in this video will work just as well step number one step number one is peel or the stove fuzzball you filthy feline step number one is not pee all over your stove step number one is clean it with a microfiber cloth and some Dawn dish soap get you a microfiber cloth and good and wet pour some Dawn dish soap in it and just start wiping down that stovetop wiping away the grease the food etc if you have any knobs take those knobs off you're gonna want to wash those in the sink with Dawn dish soap as well the next part of this step after you've wiped down the stove real real well with your dawn take your cloth over to the sink rinse out all the grease all the food particles get all the soap out of the cloth wring it dry and just come over to the stove and wipe it off step number two use your razor blade to remove the burn rings this stuff is like burned on pan residue maybe some burnt on grease but it comes off nicely with a fresh new razor blade just make sure you don't use a rusty razor blade because it could potentially scratch the service make sure that razor blade is fresh and new so that's it two simple steps to help you clean your glass stovetop if you liked this video leave me a comment down below subscribe to the channel for more great cleaning videos and as mr. fuzzball here would say meow meow now get in that kitchen and make me some homemade Fancy Feast

moisture in the wood it has helped when I've left a little bit of ash on the on the glass so what we do and I've been doing this for the last couple years and it works really well is to take a paper towel and this is a wet paper towel and I'm just gonna dip it into this ash bed here and this becomes like a pumice so I'm gonna rub that and I'm gonna have to put you down here on the tripod alright so I'm just getting into this really fine ash over here and you can see just by doing this a little bit you can see my hand through it where you couldn't before so I just keep dabbing this here getting this fine pumice like or ash effective it works very well all of this but I do this every oh I don't know three three or so fires I didn't do it for a long time and it built up I thought I title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove
original_title: How To Clean  A Glass Stove Top | Norwex Cleaning Paste | Episode 141
content: hey guys welcome back to my channel in today's video I'll be showing you guys how I clean my stovetop this is a very highly requested video you guys have sent me messages left comments down below asking me how I keep my stovetop clean so I decided to make a video showing you guys exactly the products that I use to keep my stovetop clean to start I want to start by letting you guys know that I've had this stove for six years we purchased it in 2012 when we first moved into our house so it's been about six years since I've had it so the first thing I do to keep it clean is when I'm cooking whenever I have any spills while while I cook I usually use disposable or a reusable paper or towel or whatever and get it wet in some water and as I'm cooking I just kind of wipe off the spills just so it's not a heavy-duty cleaning when it's time for me to clean my stool so as you're cooking just wipe off whatever spills on your stovetop but the main thing that I do use to clean my stove is this cleaning paste that I got from Norwex my neighbor actually sell this stuff but I'm sure if you google it you can try to find it online even on Amazon you might find it on Amazon but it's really really good just clean your stuff top it's a paste it comes like this and I've had this for at least five years it goes a long ways so what I normally do I would normally get my stovetop wet and then take some of that paste and just break it up and I would use a wet cloth and just basically scrub my stovetop and this should not scratch it at all at all and as you can see it's getting read it's getting rid of a lot of the stuff on there you guys can see that so then you just want to go ahead and wipe it off and another thing that I use if I have really stubborn dirt that won't come off I use a piece of this SOS sponge or I don't know what you call this but I'll leave the picture so you guys can see it but anyways I get it wet it already have soap in it and I just lightly scrub that part and it will not scratch your stovetop if you lightly do it the only reason I have the scratches like I said it's because I mean the stove I had for six years like I said it's not going to stay brand new especially I do a lot of cooking so of course it's not going to be new forever it's going to get some type of scratch so now all you want to do is just wipe it off and of course you want to get no clean water and just clean off your stove so I'm gonna go ahead and dump this water and then come back and show you guys how it looks okay guys this is the pad that I was using it's called brillo I thought it was my SOS which is almost the same thing but my stuff now is nice and clean like I said you have some scratches of course I use heavy duty pots to cope with but for the most part this is all I use and thank you guys for requesting that video and please don't forget to go check me out on Facebook Instagram and come snap with me on snapchat and of course on Twitter and I will leave the link for those down in the description box and this will do it for this video guys please don't forget to subscribe to the channel comment like and please please share this video and it's always thank you guys so so much for watching if this video was helpful please give it a big thumbs up and I love you guys for watching see you in my next video bye bye [Music]

title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove
original_title: Tips on cleaning your ceramic stove top
content: hi this is Teresa with sjk cleaning if you ever had that baked-on mess on top of your ceramic top stove let me help you with that the baked on stuff can be easily taken off with a razor blade that you take and put it at a very sharp degree in angle never take the razor blade straight up but take your razor blade at an angle and just little by little take off the blackened parts that you have on your stovetop especially around where your pots and pans go take a nice microfiber rag and just wipe it right up Oh still a little warm okay this is our last step we're going to use some orange glow with wood furniture and a microfiber cloth and we're just going to give the stovetop a couple of little spritzes there and with your microfiber go ahead and buff out that and here you have a very beautiful very shiny very clean ceramic stovetop all right thank you

original_title: How to Clean your Wood Stove to Keep it in Tip Top Shape
content: hello I'm Melissa from Northland Express and in this video I'll be talking about how to keep your wood stove clean I'll cover the four main areas of your stove that you should focus on and how frequently I love my wood stove and it works hard for me to keep my home warm and my energy cost down over the years I've learned a lot about caring for wood stoves and I'd like to share that information with you as well so that your job can be easier and you can help keep your wood stove going when you need it to the four main areas of your stove that you'll want to pay attention to are the exterior the interior the flue and the glass door I'll start first by talking about the exterior of your stove and how often you'll need to clean it and what you'll need to clean it obviously if you spill something on your wood stove you should clean it up right away just remember if you're burning with your stove at the time it will be hot so use caution with wiping it off as well as consideration when you use something to wipe it off with the exterior of your stove we'll get dusty from the ash and that's easily remedied with a damp cloth or dry microfiber cloth when the stove is cooled if you notice that your stove is looking tired or worn you can also use stove polishes to bring its look back to life if you spill water on your stove while you're filling your steamer try not to let that sit there as it could leave behind mineral deposits as the water evaporates or lead to rusting of your stove which isn't going to look very good keeping the exterior of your stove looking clean will be something that you need to do quite frequently when the stove is in use during the off season you really only need to keep it dusted another area of your exterior portion of your stove to check frequently when in use is the blower the blower is going to collect hair and dust as it runs and keeping that it clean is only going to extend the life of your stoves blower the next area of your stove that you're going to need to clean frequently is the interior of the stove you'll want to be removing the ashes as they accumulate if you're going to restock your fire make sure that you do leave some ashes in there that's going to help insulate the firebox which is going to ease your fire starting process if you're not going to be burning then you should completely remove the ashes and dispose of them safely the best way to remove ashes whether restarting or just going to empty them out completely from your wood stove is to use your tool set shovel as well as an ash bucket that's going to be metal no plastic should ever be used when it comes to removing ashes or hot coals from your wood stove I also recommend having an ash vacuum this is going to be the only safe way that you can suck up cool ashes from your firebox or your hearth area don't ever try and use your household vacuum that's a great way to set your vacuum on fire and end up buying a new one a tip that I have for you is when you're placing the ashes into the ash bucket move slowly this is going to have you avoid a plume of ash going up and into your air and all over your hearth and stove so you have to clean it again when you're cleaning out the ashes from your stove use this time also to check the fire bricks inside of your firebox for cracks any of those that are cracked should be replaced for title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove
original_title: How To Clean Gas Fireplace Glass
content: glass cleaning to begin cleaning the glass on your Napoleon fireplace it's important that the fireplace be turned off and the glass is cool refer to the installation manual provided with your fireplace to determine the proper procedure for opening the glass door on your model on this model we must first remove the upper louver assembly and then open the lower louver panel which provides access to the upper and lower door latches disengage the latches and the door will swing open use only a gas fireplace glass cleaner from your local Napoleon dealer do not use ammonia based products such as Windex which can have an adverse effect on the glass apply a small amount of cleaner to a soft dry cloth wipe the glass in a circular motion until you feel the cloth easily gliding across the glass surface which indicates that any buildup on the glass has been cleaned off allow the glass to dry then take another clean dry cloth and buff the remaining cleaner from the surface once completed the door can then be closed and the unit can be ready to burn

transcript.text: glass cleaning to begin cleaning the
glass on your Napoleon fireplace it's
important that the fireplace be turned
off and the glass is cool refer to the
installation manual provided with your
fireplace to determine the proper
procedure for opening the glass door on
your model on this model we must first
remove the upper louver assembly and
then open the lower louver panel which
provides access to the upper and lower
door latches disengage the latches and
the door will swing open use only a gas
fireplace glass cleaner from your local
Napoleon dealer do not use ammonia based
products such as Windex which can have
an adverse effect on the glass apply a
small amount of cleaner to a soft dry
cloth wipe the glass in a circular
motion until you feel the cloth easily
gliding across the glass surface which
indicates that any buildup on the glass
has been cleaned off allow the glass to
dry then take another clean dry cloth
and buff the remaining cleaner from the
surface once completed the door can then
be closed and the unit can be ready to
burn

title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove
original_title: How to Clean Stove Burners
content: no matter what type of cooktop you have it can be sparkling clean with these helpful tips to clean cooked on stains on a glass cooktop use a single edge scraper soak the problem area and the strongest cleaner your cooktop can handle and let it sit then scrape slowly firmly and carefully holding the blade at a 30 to 40 degree angle don't press too hard and don't hold the scraper at a high angle now wipe the cooktop clean if the manual on your gas cooktop says it's okay you can run the grates to the dishwasher on a regular basis for cooked on stains soak the grates in warm soapy water in the sink or a tub scrub the grates gently if they aren't coated you can use a gentle scouring pad for coated grates use a sponge remove electric coil burners for easy cleaning gently unplug the burner and wipe it with a sponge soaked in warm soapy water be careful not to get the electrical connection wet rinse and dry thoroughly before reattaching

title: How to Clean a Glass Top Stove
original_title: Cleaning your Ceramic Glass Cooktop
content: always read you're using care guide this video is for informational purposes only hi I'm chef Anne Noland today I'm going to talk to you about properly cleaning your ceramic glass cooktop your cooktop should be cleaned after each use follow these three easy steps to keep it looking like new for years scrape off any food or residue with a razor for best results use this scraper while the cooktop is still warm but not hot to the touch we recommend wearing an oven mitt while scraping the warm cooktop hold the blade at a 45 degree angle and apply pressure to remove the residue once the cooktop is cool apply a few drops of a fresh cooktop cleaner onto the affected areas rub the cleaner on the cooktop surface with the blue scrubbing pad apply pressure to remove stubborn stains after letting the cleaner dry to a white haze polish the cooktop with a clean dry cloth or a clean dry paper towel for stubborn stains you may have to repeat this process more than once to order cleaning supplies please see the use and care manual that came with your product follow these three steps and you'll keep your cooktop looking new thanks for watching
